Dear Mrs. Fernandez:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 For repeat violations identify why the previous CAP was unsuccessful.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and
your contract.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the local office at (866) 685-0006.

ALLEGATION:
There is not enough staff at facility. There are 50 children and 8 staff total. The youth
being serviced have various mental/physical health issues and some are sexual
predators with access to younger youth. Supervision is compromised and upper
management has been unresponsive to this issue for up to a year.
INVESTIGATION:
This complaint was transferred for investigation on 10/11/21. The complaint noted
the following,
There is not enough staff in the facility. There are 50 children and 8 staff all
together. The children in the facility have various mental and physical health
issues. Some of the children are highly sexual predators with access to younger
children. This continues to happen where there is not enough on campus.
Yesterday the same thing happened. The upper management is not answering
the phone or returning calls. This has been going on for the last 6 months to a
year. It has gotten worse in the last 30 days.
I interviewed the complainant via phone on 10/11/21. The complainant reported
some concerns that have been investigated outside of this investigation and are not
duplicated in this report. Complaints related to staffing a youth at the hospital on the
weekend of 10/09/21-10/10/21, and that there was no supervisor on duty for the
same weekend were investigated in SIR 2022C0108003. The complainant reported
that they worked both days the prior weekend, 10/09/21 and 10/10/21. These were
the first days back to work for the complainant after six months. The complainant
4

reported working at the facility for about six months and was laid off. The
complainant said that she filed a grievance with the union and was brought back to
work on 10/09/21. Upon return to work the complainant said that they were short
staffed both days that weekend in Stoner cottage. The complainant said that they
were the only staff there upon arriving at 10:30am on 10/09/21. Upon arrival, the
complainant said Staff 3 was alone with seven kids and after Staff 3 left, the
complainant was left alone with all seven. The complainant reported that other
cottages had sufficient and extra staff that could have been used in their cottage.
The complainant said that when they returned to work on 10/10/21 they were again
alone with seven or eight kids. The complainant said that they made the
administration move some kids to another cottage so that they would be in ratio of
one staff per four youth. The complainant said that it was the Director of Children’s
Services who began moving youth as the complainant was late coming in to work.
The complainant said, “It’s a mess over there” and said that they are not disgruntled
but fed up with the facility doing “whatever” to the staff and not protecting the
residents. When asked if the complainant had spoken to the Director of Residential
Services (DRS), the complainant said that the DRS was fired the week prior. The
complainant said that since she just returned to work, she doesn’t know all the staff,
but knew Staff 2 came in on 10/9/21 “for a while” because she forgot something and
stayed with the complainant for a while. The complainant also said that Staff 2
worked on 10/10/21 at 3:00pm.
The complainant called again on 11/08/21 and reviewed the issues of concern. The
complainant reported that no additional staff were sent to the cottage on 10/09/21.
The complainant said that she was working alone on 10/10/21 until about 2:30 or
3:00pm when Staff 2 came in. The complainant said that she was terminated on
10/15/21 because the facility said she left from her assignment to staff a youth at the
hospital.
I visited the facility on the following days and checked for compliance with staffing
and ratio. One of the six cottages is having renovations done and not in use. The
following is what was observed:
 10/12/21-I toured the five occupied cottages, and all were in ratio. Youth were
on the playground and were observed to be in ratio.
 10/21/21-I toured one cottage, Ott, and they were in ratio.
 10/27/21- I toured the five occupied cottages and all were in ratio. Youth were
on the playground and were observed to be in ratio.
 11/10/21- I toured the five occupied cottages and all were in ratio.
I interviewed the Director of Clinical Services at the facility, on 10/21/21. The
Director of Clinical Services (DCS) said that he was an on-call administrator for part
of the weekend and spoke with the complainant, who is a staff at the facility. The
DCS said he spoke to the complainant about 16 times due to a situation that
occurred with youth truancy and the DCS coordinating for the complainant to go up
to the hospital to monitor a youth. The DCS said that he was also in contact with the
Supervisor that weekend during this incident. The DCS said that the complainant
5

was worried about being held over at the hospital as they have another job, so the
DCS and Supervisor got coverage for the complaint to be relieved. The DCS said
that the complainant was upset because she had to go monitor the youth at the
hospital.
I interviewed the Director of Children’s Services at the facility, on 10/21/21. The
Director of Children’s Services said that she was the on-call administrator for part of
the weekend and received a call from Staff 3 who was asking who was coming in to
relieve him as the complainant had called and said she was going to be late. The
Director of Children’s Services called other cottages to see who was working and
began moving youth and staff around to ensure staffing ratios were in compliance.
The Director of Children’s Services said that she planned out the adjustments and
they would have ensured compliance with ratio. The Director of Children’s Services
also came on campus on 10/10/21 from about 4:00pm through 8:00pm to assist as
they were short supervisors for the campus (addressed in SIR 2022C0108003). The
Director of Children’s Services said that the complainant was not the only staff
working in the cottage on 10/10/21 and reported that Staff 2 came in as well.
I interviewed the Supervisor at the facility, on 10/21/21. The Supervisor said that, on
10/09/21, he was on campus and worked from 11:00am-11:00pm. On 10/09/21, the
Supervisor reported that he moved some youth from the complainant’s cottage to
ensure ratio because the complainant was initially out of ratio with about eight youth
and only herself there. This was resolved when the Supervisor arrived and moved
some youth. The Supervisor was not scheduled, nor on-call, for 10/10/21, but came
in to assist during an emergency. On 10/10/21, he took another staff up to the
hospital to relieve the complainant.
A PCU phone conference was held on 10/25/21 that included numerous
representatives for the residents at the facility. Some participants voiced concerns
related to staffing and other issues, while others reported no concerns with staffing
levels. I advised that if there were specific licensing complaints unrelated to the
current staffing and ratio complaint being investigated, for those complaints to be
reported.
Complainant 2 emailed on 10/27/21, to advise that Youth J is not being supervised
by the facility during his visits with his mother, as required, due to lack of staffing.
Complainant 2 said that Youth J has visits with his mother, whose parental rights
have been terminated. This is allowed per the youth’s trauma assessment. The visits
occur every other Saturday at Methodist and the case manager agreed to ensure
adequate staffing to supervise the visits. Per Complainant 2, Witness 3 reported that
two recent visits between Youth J and his mother were on campus but not
supervised by staff. Witness 2, who is Youth J’s foster care worker, requested
visitation reports from the facility and Youth J’s Family Transition Coordinator
indicated that Youth A and his mother are not actually being supervised as
requested. Complainant 2 forwarded an email from the Family Transition
Coordinator to Witness 2 regarding the supervised visits. In part, the email noted the
6

following, “I have not been able to supervise the last two personally as I typically do
not work weekends. We do not have extra staff on weekends so the on-call
supervisor observes the interactions, when possible, but they are also responsible
for any other crises that may occur on campus, so they are not able to provide a
detailed report.”
I interviewed Youth J at the facility on 10/27/21. Youth J reported that the last two of
the three visits he has had with his mother have not been supervised by the facility.
On 11/16/21, the Director of Children’s Services reported the following, via email,
related to the supervised visits.
To my knowledge all of Youth J’s visits with his Mom were supervised. The FTC
supervised the first visit and had reached out to the FC Worker after the visit
updating her about how it went and asked whether visits needed to continue to
be supervised (because the visit went well and phone contact was no longer
supervised). The FC worker said that she wanted the next couple of visits to be
supervised and if those went well then they could be moved to unsupervised. At
the next couple of visits Youth J and his Mom were outside and were within
staff’s line of sight.
The Director also reported in a subsequent email on 11/17/21, that the Supervisor
supervised the visits on 10/02/21 and 10/16/21.
I interviewed Witness 3 via phone on 11/22/21. Witness 3 reported that visits
between Youth J and his mother were not supervised on 10/02/21 or 10/16/21. The
mother reportedly spoke to the Supervisor, but the mother and Youth J walked
campus together but did not have a staff with them or near them. The mother had to
call the on-call number to get someone to let her in a building to use the restroom on
10/02/21, as no one was around. Reportedly, the mother is concerned as her visits
are supposed to be supervised and she doesn’t want to get in trouble with the court
if the facility is not doing what they are supposed to do.
I met with the Director of Residential Services (DRS) on 11/10/21 and exchanged
information via email throughout this investigation. The DRS provided copies of staff
schedules for the weekend noted in this complaint. Specifically, the Stoner cottage
where the complainant alleged ratio was not followed was verified for compliance.
The DRS updated the schedule and reported that she confirmed it was accurate with
the human resources department and the shift reports. Documentation was also
provided related to youth being on home passes during that weekend, for
confirmation of ratio compliance.
I interviewed Staff 2 via phone on 11/22/21. Staff 2 confirmed that she worked
10/09/21 from 11:00am-7:00pm, and 10/10/21 from 6:30am-10:30pm. Staff 2
reported that she “thinks we were in ratio,” noting the Supervisor moved some kids
and staff around to maintain staffing ratios. Staff 2 reported that since she has been
there (two months) that she has not worked out of ratio.
7

I met with the Chief Administrator at the facility on 11/23/21, and the complainant’s
employee file was reviewed. A notice of indefinite layoff was in the file and dated
04/16/21 due to the complainant’s assigned cottage closing and the limited
availability of open shifts. The Chief Administrator reported that the complainant did
not work for the facility at the time this occurred, but she confirmed with Human
Resources that the complainant did not want to work in the available cottages with
shift openings, so she was laid off. There was also a notification of administrative
leave in the complainant’s file, dated 10/15/21. The complainant was put on unpaid
administrative leave pending an open investigation. The Chief Administrator reported
that the investigation was internal and related to the complainant reportedly being
verbally aggressive and insubordinate with the Supervisor and the Director of
Clinical Services on the weekend of 10/09/21-10/10/21. This investigation was noted
to still be with the Licensee Designee for review. Finally, the 180-day performance
evaluation for the complainant from her original hire date was reviewed. It was dated
05/06/20 and noted that she “meets requirements” in all areas except for
attendance.
I interviewed the Supervisor via phone on 12/01/21. The Supervisor verified that he
was asked to supervise visits for Youth J and his mother in October but clarified that
he was told that Youth J and the mother could be in the common area outside of the
cottages as long as they were in line of sight. The Supervisor said that he was told
he did not need to be sitting with them or within sound of the visit, but could not
recall who told him that, although he thought it was the Family Transition
Coordinator. The Supervisor said that he was the on-duty supervisor those days and
attending to other things, and there were no extra staff to assign to monitor the visit,
so he would look out at Youth J and his mother but was not continuously present for
the visit. The Supervisor said that he was first asked to supervise the visit in the
Fairman cottage but told (whoever it was) that it would depend on if they had enough
staff on the weekend to do so. Since this issue surfaced, the Supervisor said that the
administration addressed with the staff that supervised visits are to have an
assigned staff within sight and sound of the visit.
Staff schedules and email verification of youth on home passes were provided for
review. Specific to the weekend of this complaint and for the noted cottage, the
following was observed for 10/09/21. The schedule for 10/10/21 shows the facility to
be in ratio.
 Staff 3 worked from 8:30pm on 10/08/21 until 10:30am on 10/09/21. There
were eight youth in the cottage during this time.
 The complainant worked from 10:30am – 10:30pm on 10/09/21. There were
eight youth in the cottage on this day until noon, when one youth went on a
day pass. At that time there were seven remaining in the cottage.
 Staff 2 worked 11:00am – 7:00pm.
 Two additional staff came in later in the day at 12:30pm and 4:23pm
respectively.
 One staff called in sick.
8

A list of residential employees was provided and noted 55 employees from the Chief
Administrator to part time contingent staff; 51 of the employees were designated
supervisors and direct care staff.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4126 Sufficiency of staff.
The licensee shall have a sufficient number of
administrative, supervisory, social service, direct care, and
other staff on duty to perform the prescribed functions
required by these administrative rules and in the agency's
program statement and to provide for the continual needs,
protection, and supervision of residents.
ANALYSIS: The facility is in violation as the evidence supports that there are
not always sufficient staff to provide for the needs, protection,
and supervision of residents. In this case, Youth J was
supposed to have supervised visits, but the facility did not
supervise at least two of his visits.
CONCLUSION: REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
SIR 2022C0108003, intake 10/11/21, CAP approved 11/16/21
SIR 2020C0108009, intake 11/26/19, CAP approved 01/13/20
SIR 2022C0207005, intake 10/25/21, CAP pending
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4127 Staff-to-resident ratio.
(1) The licensee shall develop and adhere to a written staff-
to-resident ratio formula for direct care workers.
ANALYSIS: The facility is in violation as the evidence supports the allegation
that, on 10/09/21, the facility was out of ratio. Staff 1 reported
this, and the staff schedule provided by the administration
showed them to be out of ratio that morning.
CONCLUSION: REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
SIR 2021C0207024, intake 07/20/21, CAP approved 09/22/21
SIR 2021C0108045, intake 07/13/21, CAP approved 08/25/21
(cited as a contract violation for ratio)
SIR 2022C0207005, intake 10/25/21, CAP pending
9

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on the findings of this investigation, I recommend no change to the current
license status. This recommendation is contingent on the facility submitting an
acceptable corrective action plan for the noted violations.
